questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of concern that he has not yet begun to walk. He was born at term and exclusively breastfed until 15 months of age. His mother says he has been well, apart from an episode of high fever and seizure 4 months ago for which she did not seek medical attention. He has an older brother who is currently receiving medical treatment for failure to thrive. His parents have no history of serious illness; they are of normal height. His last vaccine was at the age of 4 months. He has never received any supplements or medications. He is at the 20th percentile for length, 10th percentile for weight, and 50th percentile for head circumference. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes, erosion of the enamel on the lingual surface of the incisors, and carious molars. He has frontal bossing. His wrists are widened, and his legs seem bent. Palpation of the chest shows nodular deformities at the costochondral junctions. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's delay in walking?

choices.text: Multiple bone fractures in different stages of healing
Deficiency of cofactor for prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase
Mutation of fibroblast growth factor receptor 3
Deficiency of osteoclasts to reabsorb bone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple fractures at different stages of healing should raise concern for child abuse. In preambulatory children, specific fractures (e.g., of the ribs, scapula, hands/fingers, and spiral fractures of the femur), are especially concerning. Although this patient has various joint, craniofacial, chest wall, and dental anomalies, his presentation is more concerning for neglect (as suggested by dry mucous membranes, lack of vaccinations, late weaning) rather than child abuse.

B) INCORRECT:

Type I collagen defects cause osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), which manifests with very fragile bones that are prone to fracture from minimal trauma. Other classic findings include blue sclerae, poor hearing, and dental abnormalities. While this patient has skeletal abnormalities, he has no history of recurrent fractures or blue sclerae. Moreover, OI does not cause joint abnormalities.

C) CORRECT:

Defective growth plate mineralization due to vitamin D deficiency is the cause of rickets. The impaired bone mineralization leads to bead-like costochondral junctions (“rachitic rosary”), erosion of tooth enamel, bone pain and weakening (frontal bossing), abnormal bowing (genu varum), and distention of the bone (widened joints). These bone deformities are responsible for the delay in this patient's walking. Dietary changes (increased vitamin D, calcium, and phosphate intake) and adequate sun exposure are the first-line treatments for rickets.

This patient's malnutrition seems to arise from domestic neglect as suggested by the elder sibling's failure to thrive, the lack of medical attention after a seizure, the lack of vaccinations, and improper feeding practices (i.e., late introduction of solid foods, lack of vitamin D supplementation during first year of life).

D) INCORRECT:

The cofactor for prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase is ascorbic acid (vitamin C). Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, which classically manifests with weakness and fatigue (early), followed by mucosal bleeding, curly hair, poor wound healing, and increased susceptibility to severe infection (late). This patient's presentation is inconsistent with scurvy.

E) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 gene cause achondroplasia, which manifests with short stature and frontal prominence. However, height is usually below the 5th percentile in achondroplasia. Moreover, this condition is not associated with dental changes or beading of the ribs. Instead, skeletal abnormalities such as microcephaly, short extremities, and scoliosis are typically seen in achondroplasia.

F) INCORRECT:

Deficient osteoclast-mediated bone resorption is the pathophysiologic mechanism of osteopetrosis. This condition is extremely rare in the pediatric population. Most often, these patients present with cranial nerve palsies (from cranial foramen narrowing), hip abnormalities, and an increased tendency for long bone fractures. This patient does exhibit long bone and joint abnormalities, but he lacks fractures or cranial nerve palsies. In addition, osteopetrosis does not result in dental and craniofacial abnormalities or beading of the ribs.
Image Description:

Anteroposterior x-ray of the hand of an 8-year-old girl: pronounced metaphyseal densities in line with increased sclerotization of the bones of the fingers.
questions.hint: Frontal bossing, beading of the ribs, widened wrists, bowing of the legs, and erosion of tooth enamel suggest vitamin D deficiency. As this patient has been exclusively breastfed without supplementation until recently, vitamin D deficiency is likely a result of low oral intake, because breast milk only has low amounts of vitamin D.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother for a 1-hour history of severe right-sided leg pain. The mother says he fell while playing with his friends at the playground and since then has not been able to stand on his right leg. Medical history is remarkable for cystic fibrosis. He is at the 15th percentile for height and the 10th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows mild swelling of the right lower leg and a small, soft anterior fontanelle. Palpation of the skull shows flexibility of the occipital and parietal bones when pressure is applied. X-ray of the lower extremities discloses a diaphyseal fracture of the right tibia. There are multiple transverse radiolucent band-like lesions with sclerotic margins in the tibial and fibular shafts bilaterally. Serum studies are most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?



Calcium
Phosphate
Alkaline phosphatases
Parathyroid hormone



A
Normal
normal
increased
normal


B
Normal
normal
normal
normal


C
Increased
decreased
increased
increased


D
Decreased
decreased
increased
increased


E
Decreased
increased
normal
decreased


F
Decreased
increased
increased
increased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High serum alkaline phosphatase and normal calcium, phosphorus, and parathyroid hormone levels are characteristic of Paget disease of the bone (PDB), which can manifest with pathological fractures of long bones (chalk stick fractures). While PDB lesions can have a mixed lytic (radiolucent) and sclerotic appearance on x-ray, they typically appear as lytic lesions within a background of diffuse sclerosis; Looser zones are not characteristic of PDB. Furthermore, PDB is rare in young children, and it causes skull enlargement rather than delayed fontanelle closure and craniotabes.

B) INCORRECT:

Normal calcium, phosphorus, parathyroid hormone, and alkaline phosphatase levels are seen in osteoporosis, which can manifest with pathological fractures and increased radiolucency on x-ray because of decreased bone density. However, in osteoporosis, the bone appears diffusely radiolucent on x-ray, in contrast with this patient's transverse band-like lesions with sclerotic margins. Moreover, osteoporosis is rare in young children.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased phosphate and increased calcium, alkaline phosphatase, and parathyroid hormone levels are characteristic of primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT), which can manifest with focal osteolytic lesions (osteitis fibrosa cystica) on x-ray. However, osteolytic lesions in a patient with PHPT are usually round/polygonal and circumscribed, unlike the distinctive transverse band-like lesions seen here. Although PHPT is common among adults, it only rarely affects children (e.g., children with MEN 1 syndrome).

D) CORRECT:

Vitamin D deficiency causes hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia by decreasing calcium and phosphate absorption in the intestine. Hypocalcemia leads to increased parathyroid hormone secretion (secondary hyperparathyroidism), which increases bone turnover and mobilizes the calcium stored in bones; increased bone turnover is indicated by high levels of alkaline phosphatase. High levels of parathyroid hormone also worsen hypophosphatemia by decreasing renal phosphate reabsorption. In children, these mechanisms ultimately lead to rickets due to defective bone and cartilaginous growth plate mineralization.

Other typical manifestations of rickets include bending of the long bones, genu varum, distention of the bone-cartilage junctions (e.g., rachitic rosary and Marfan sign), Harrison groove, and symptoms of hypocalcemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased calcium and parathyroid hormone levels with normal serum alkaline phosphatase levels and increased phosphate are consistent with primary hypoparathyroidism. Features of bone disease are usually absent in individuals with this condition. Although primary hypoparathyroidism can be seen in infants with DiGeorge syndrome or autoimmune conditions, it is most commonly caused by iatrogenic damage to the parathyroid glands during neck surgery (e.g., thyroidectomy) or neck irradiation in adults.

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased calcium and increased phosphate, alkaline phosphatase, and parathyroid hormone levels are seen in patients with pseudohypoparathyroidism (PHP), which typically manifests during childhood. In PHP, renal end-organ resistance to parathyroid hormone can result in focal osteolytic bone lesions (renal osteodystrophy, osteitis fibrosa cystica). However, most affected individuals also present with features of Albright hereditary osteodystrophy (e.g., round face, obesity, short fourth metacarpals, soft tissue calcifications, dental hypoplasia). This set of findings could also be seen in patients with secondary hyperparathyroidism due to advanced chronic kidney disease, which is unlikely in a child with no history of renal disease.
questions.hint: This patient's findings of delayed fontanelle closure, craniotabes, and impaired growth in combination with Looser zones (i.e., transverse radiolucent lesions) on x-ray indicate rickets. Individuals with cystic fibrosis are at increased risk of developing this condition due to impaired absorption of vitamin D.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain for 2 days. The pain began after she did some household chores and has since limited her daily activities; the patient identifies the pain as 7 out of 10 in intensity. Over the past 2 years she has had intermittent diarrhea, bloating, and a 15-kg (33-lb) weight loss. She has not seen a doctor in a few years. Menarche occurred at the age of 13 years and her periods are irregular. There is no family history of serious illness. She is inconsistent with her dietary habits and does not always have a good appetite. She takes walks in the park daily. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her only medication is insulin. She appears pale. She is 153 cm (5 ft) tall and weighs 40 kg (88 lb); BMI is 17 kg/m2. Examination of the back shows spinal tenderness at the T12 vertebral level. There is proximal muscle weakness in the lower limbs. Cardiopulmonary, neurologic, and pelvic examinations show no abnormalities. A test of the stool for occult blood is negative. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9000/mm3



Platelet count
230,000/mm3



Mean corpuscular volume
68 μm3



HbA1C

5.2%


Serum



 Sodium
134 mEq/dL


 Potassium
4.1 mEq/dL


 Calcium

8.2 mg/dL


 Phosphorus

2.7 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


An x-ray of the spine shows a compression fracture of the T12 vertebra. Which of the following is the primary mechanism underlying this patient's musculoskeletal symptoms?

choices.text: Impaired cholecalciferol synthesis in the skin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cholecalciferol is derived in the skin from 7-dehydrocholesterol during exposure to sunlight (UVB radiation). Reduced sun exposure can lead to vitamin D deficiency and resulting hypocalcemia. However, this patient's history of daily walks in the park lowers her risk of insufficient sunlight exposure. Moreover, her history of diarrhea, bloating, and microcytic anemia are more suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Low dietary intake of calcium can cause chronic hypocalcemia, which can lead to osteopenia and osteoporosis. Although this patient's compression fracture is consistent with osteoporosis, the laboratory changes (hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia) and muscle weakness are not. While inadequate calcium intake may also contribute to the development of osteomalacia, it is not the primary pathomechanism. Instead, her history of diarrhea, bloating, and weight loss indicate a different underlying cause.

C) CORRECT:

Intermittent diarrhea, bloating, and weight loss in combination with microcytic anemia in a young patient with type 1 diabetes mellitus are concerning for celiac disease (CD). Intestinal malabsorption (e.g., due to CD) can cause vitamin D deficiency and subsequent osteomalacia, which leads to impaired mineralization of osteoid. Manifestations of osteomalacia include bone pain and tenderness, pathological fractures, a waddling gait and difficulty walking, myopathy, and symptoms of hypocalcemia. Individuals with CD are also at increased risk of developing osteoporosis.

Further causes of vitamin D deficiency include insufficient sun exposure, low dietary Vitamin D intake, treatment with cytochrome P450 inducers (e.g., anticonvulsants, certain antibiotics), and impaired organ function (e.g., liver cirrhosis, chronic kidney disease). Vitamin D supplementation and treatment of any underlying condition are the therapies of choice.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypocalcemia can occur as a result of hypoparathyroidism, which is caused by autoimmune destruction of the parathyroid glands. Because this patient has a history of type 1 diabetes, autoimmune hypoparathyroidism is a possibility. However, anemia and proximal muscle weakness cannot be explained solely by this condition. Moreover, diarrhea, bloating, and weight loss observed in this patient are not expected in hypoparathyroidism.

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired hydroxylation of calcifediol (25-hydroxyvitamin D) to calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D) is caused by decreased 1-alpha-hydroxylase activity in chronic kidney disease (CKD). CKD can lead to renal osteodystrophy and manifest with osteomalacia and bone pain. Reduction in 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels results in hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and secondary hyperparathyroidism. However, this patient's normal creatinine is inconsistent with CKD. Moreover, impaired hydroxylation of calcifediol does not explain this patient's diarrhea, bloating, or weight loss. While CKD can cause anemia due to decreased erythropoietin production, the anemia of CKD is usually normocytic and normochromic.
questions.hint: This patient has bone pain due to a spinal fracture that occurred with minimal trauma, which is concerning for a pathologic fracture. These findings in addition to muscle weakness, hypocalcemia, and hypophosphatemia raise concern for osteomalacia.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother has noticed that he frequently falls while running. He was born at term and the pregnancy was uncomplicated. He has a seizure disorder treated with phenytoin. He is at the 20th percentile for height and at 30th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows decreased muscle strength in the lower extremities. There is a deep groove below the costal margins bilaterally. An x-ray of the lower extremities is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While genu varum is a normal finding in newborns, infants, and toddlers (physiological varus), the lower limbs gradually straighten until 2 years of age. The presence of varus beyond 2 years of age, along with the other clinical features with which this 6-year-old child presents, is suggestive of a pathological varus deformity.

B) INCORRECT:

Although an epiphyseal plate fracture (i.e., Salter-Harris fracture) could cause angular deformities of the affected limb (e.g., genu varum), a bilateral symmetrical occurrence is highly unlikely and would not explain this patient's other clinical features. More importantly, he has no signs of healing fractures on the x-ray, nor a history of pain, swelling, and inability to bear weight on the affected side.

C) INCORRECT:

Disruption of normal cartilage growth at the proximal tibial epiphyseal plate results in Blount disease. This condition causes bowed legs in young children, but the pathology is localized to the proximal tibial epiphyseal plates and does not explain the myopathy or the subcostal groove seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

This boy presents with rickets, a condition characterized by defective bone and epiphyseal plate mineralization due to vitamin D deficiency. In this patient, this condition is most likely due to an altered vitamin D metabolism as an adverse effect of the anticonvulsant treatment he is receiving. Phenytoin, a cytochrome P450 inducer increases the catabolism of vitamin D into inactive metabolites. Decreased vitamin D levels reduce intestinal calcium absorption, resulting in hypocalcemia, secondary hyperparathyroidism, and secondary hypophosphatemia, which impair bone calcification and mineralization. Typical clinical features of rickets include myopathy, Harrison groove, genu varum, bowing of the long bones of the lower limbs, and widening of the epiphyseal plates.

The most common cause of rickets is inadequate intake of vitamin D and/or calcium.

E) INCORRECT:

Skeletal dysplasias like osteogenesis imperfecta and achondroplasia can cause growth retardation and pathological genu varum. However, other characteristic features of these conditions (e.g., blue sclerae and hearing loss for osteogenesis imperfecta; macrocephaly and short, plump extremities for achondroplasia) are not present in this child. Furthermore, skeletal dysplasias do not cause myopathy or subcostal groove.

F) INCORRECT:

Certain tumors of the bone (e.g., ossifying fibroma, Ewing sarcoma, osteosarcoma, Langerhans cell histiocytosis) can cause deformities (e.g., bowing) of the affected limb in pediatric patients. However, most bone tumors are asymptomatic or present with localized pain, swelling or pathological fractures. Bilaterally symmetrical bowing of the legs, myopathy, and a subcostal groove are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Chronic exposure to lead (e.g., in soil or lead-based paint) can cause lead toxicity. Children with lead toxicity can present with growth retardation, myopathy, and pathological genu varum. However, this patient does not have other, more common symptoms of lead toxicity such as abdominal pain, anemia, gingival hyperpigmentation, and polyneuropathy. Moreover, the presence of the subcostal groove in this patient cannot be explained by lead toxicity.
questions.hint: The x-ray shows bilateral genu varum, widening of the epiphyseal plates, and metaphyseal fraying and cupping.

questions.text: An exclusively breast-fed, 5-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a routine examination. He was born at term and delivery was uncomplicated. He received all standard treatment and testing prior to being discharged from the hospital 3 days ago. Examination shows no abnormalities. Without receiving additional supplementation at this time, this newborn is at greatest risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of niacin, also known as pellagra, could result in scaly dermatitis, diarrhea, and eventually neurological symptoms (e.g., dementia). However, niacin does not typically need to be supplemented in infants' diets as adequate amounts are found in both breast milk and in most formulas. In the absence of comorbidities (e.g., malnutrition, Hartnup disease), pellagra is unlikely to develop in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

A deficiency in vitamin K greatly increases the risk of developing an intracranial bleed in early infancy. All newborn infants receive an injection of intramuscular vitamin K at birth to prevent this deficiency. This patient has already received this intervention as part of standard hospital care, and no more supplementation is necessary. Although levels of vitamin K in breast milk are low, most infants do not require additional supplementation after the initial injection, unless comorbidities are present (e.g., chronic diarrhea or long-term antibiotic treatment).

C) INCORRECT:

Underlying iron deficiency can manifest as microcytic anemia. Premature infants have lower iron stores and increased demand, and thus require supplementation in addition to the iron found in breast milk. However, exclusively breastfed infants < 4 months of age who were not born prematurely should receive adequate iron from breast milk alone. Exclusively breastfed infants ≥ 4 months of age should receive iron supplementation.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to peripheral neuropathy. However, most breastfed infants receive adequate vitamin B12 from their mother's breast milk. Vitamin B12 supplementation during infancy is typically only required when the patient's mother follows a strict vegan diet because vitamin B12 mostly comes from animal products (e.g., meat, fish, and dairy).

E) CORRECT:

The vitamin D content of breast milk is not considered to be high enough to prevent complications from developing in infants. Therefore, vitamin D supplementation is recommended in all exclusively breastfed infants until the recommended daily vitamin D intake through diet is met. Dietary sources of vitamin D include ≥ 34 oz/day of infant formula, solid foods, and, once the infant is 12 months old, vitamin D-fortified whole milk. This supplementation protects against hypocalcemia and rickets, a disease of bone deformities in children due to a deficiency of vitamin D. Rickets is characterized by impaired calcification of the bones, delayed closure of the fontanelles, frontal bossing, prominence of costochondral junctions (“rachitic rosary”), and genu valgum or genu varum. Children with rickets present with varying degrees of pain, poor growth, motor delays, and an increased risk of infections.

F) INCORRECT:

Scurvy, caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, leads to impaired collagen synthesis that would manifest with petechiae, hyperkeratosis, and coiled hairs. Vitamin C does not typically need to be supplemented in infants' diets as adequate amounts are found in both breast milk and in most formulas. Therefore, in the absence of severe malnutrition or malabsorption, this patient is unlikely to need additional vitamin C supplementation.
questions.hint: A deficiency of this micronutrient can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 16-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a regular check-up. His mother says that he has not yet begun to walk. He is exclusively breastfed. He is at the 20th percentile for length, 10th percentile for weight, and 50th percentile for head circumference. Physical examination shows erosion of the enamel on the lingual surface of the incisors and carious molars. He has frontal bossing. His wrists are widened, his legs appear bowed, and there is beading of the ribs. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Deficiency of cofactor for prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase
Osteoid proliferation in the subperiosteal bone
Mutation of fibroblast growth factor receptor 3

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The cofactor for prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase is ascorbic acid (vitamin C). Deficiency of vitamin C causes scurvy, which classically manifests with weakness and fatigue (in early stages), followed by mucosal bleeding, curly hair, poor wound healing, and increased susceptibility to severe infection (in late stages). The patient described here does not present with any of these signs or symptoms. Moreover, scurvy is uncommon, although certain at-risk populations (e.g., individuals with very restricted diets or alcohol use disorder, older individuals) are susceptible.

B) INCORRECT:

Osteoid proliferation in the subperiosteal bone is seen in chondrodystrophy. Because many different mutations can cause chondrodystrophy, there is a wide spectrum of clinical presentations that almost always include short stature. This patient is in the low-normal range for length, but the presence of joint abnormalities and an open fontanelle indicate a different cause for his limited growth.

C) INCORRECT:

Type I collagen defects cause osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), which presents with very fragile bones that are prone to fracture from minimal trauma. Other classic findings include blue tinged sclera, poor hearing, and dental abnormalities. While this patient has skeletal abnormalities, he has no history of recurrent fractures or blue sclera. Moreover, OI would not explain the open fontanelle and the joint anomalies seen on exam.

D) CORRECT:

Impaired growth plate mineralization due to vitamin D deficiency is the cause of rickets. This infant has several risk factors for the development of vitamin D deficiency, including exclusive breastfeeding and a lack of nutritional supplementation. Vitamin D deficiency results in low calcium and phosphate levels, which, in turn, lead to defective osteogenesis and osteoclastogenesis, reduced bone volume, and malformed and enlarged growth plates. Dietary changes (increased vitamin D, calcium, and phosphate) and adequate sun exposure are the first-line treatments for rickets.

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired osteoclast-mediated bone resorption is the pathophysiologic mechanism of osteopetrosis. This condition is extremely rare in the pediatric population. Most often, these patients present with cranial nerve palsies (from cranial foramen narrowing), hip abnormalities, and an increased tendency for long bone fractures. Although this patient exhibits long bone and joint abnormalities, he lacks fractures or cranial nerve palsies. In addition, his dental and craniofacial abnormalities along with beading of the ribs are inconsistent with osteopetrosis.
Image Description:

Anteroposterior x-ray of the hand of an 8-year-old girl: pronounced metaphyseal densities in line with increased sclerotization of the bones of the fingers.

F) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 gene would lead to achondroplasia, which presents with short stature. However, height would be under the 5th percentile and would be associated with macrocephaly, neither of which are present in this patient. Also, this mutation would not explain this patient's dental changes or beading of the ribs.

The autosomal dominant inheritance pattern of achondroplasia means that there is sometimes a positive family history, but ∼ 80% of cases are caused by a spontaneous mutation.
Image Description:

Short stature and prominent lumbar lordosis can be seen in this 11-year-old patient.

This is the characteristic appearance of achondroplasia.
questions.hint: This child presents with a history of exclusive breastfeeding along with lack of supplements. His clinical features of frontal bossing, beading of the ribs (“rachitic rosary”), widened wrists, bowed legs, and erosion of tooth enamel suggest vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of generalized bone pain. She has a 25-year history of Crohn disease with multiple hospitalizations for acute exacerbations, including a bowel obstruction last year. Current medications include mesalamine and bisoprolol. She is 165 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 53 kg (117 lb); her BMI is 19.5 kg/m2. Examination shows a soft abdomen and pale conjunctivae. Neurological examination shows decreased vibratory sensation over her lower extremities. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the distal groups and 3/5 in proximal groups of the lower limbs. The pelvic bones are tender to palpation. An x-ray of the pelvis shows thin cortices and multiple radiolucent bands that are perpendicular to the cortex and surrounded by a thin sclerotic margin. Which of the following laboratory findings are most likely present in this patient?



Calcium
Phosphate
Alkaline phosphatase
Parathyroid hormone



A
Normal
normal
normal
normal


B
Normal
normal
↑
normal


C
↓
↓
↑
↑


D
↑
↓
↑
↑


E
↓
↑
↑
↑


F
↑
↑
↑
↓


G
↓
↑
normal
↓
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Normal calcium, phosphorus, PTH, and ALP levels in an elderly female patient with bone pain are characteristic of osteoporosis. Osteoporosis would result in cortical thinning and increased radiolucency due to decreased bone density. However, bone sclerosis would not be expected, and the bone would be diffusely radiolucent, in contrast to the osteolytic lesions seen in this patient, which have a distinctive transverse band-like appearance on x-ray. Moreover, osteoporosis would not explain the myopathic weakness seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

High serum ALP and normal calcium, phosphorus, and PTH levels in an elderly patient with bone pain are characteristic of Paget disease of the bone (PDB). However, while PDB lesions can have a mixed lytic (radiolucent) and sclerotic appearance, they typically appear as lytic lesions within a background of diffuse sclerosis. Furthermore, a thin cortex would not be seen in PDB.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis

Enlargement of the right hemipelvis is accompanied by coarsened trabeculation and areas of sclerosis compatible with abnormal remodeling in Paget disease (green overlay).

C) CORRECT:

Severe vitamin D deficiency can lead to hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia by decreasing the amount of calcium and phosphate absorption in the intestine. As long as calcium levels are low, increased PTH secretion occurs in an attempt to maintain normal serum calcium levels (secondary hyperparathyroidism). PTH releases calcium stored in bone into serum by increasing bone turnover, which the elevated ALP levels (a marker of bone turnover) indicate here. Increased PTH levels also worsen hypophosphatemia by decreasing renal phosphate reabsorption.

Chronic inflammation of the ileum in patients with Crohn disease can cause impaired reabsorption of bile acids, resulting in fat malabsorption; unabsorbed fats can trap fat-soluble vitamins (e.g., vitamin D) in the intestinal lumen, causing a deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased phosphate and increased calcium, ALP, and PTH levels are characteristic of primary hyperparathyroidism, which typically occurs in elderly women and causes bone pain. A pelvic x-ray in a patient with primary hyperparathyroidism can show cortical thinning as well as focal osteolytic lesions. However, the osteolytic lesions in patients with primary hyperparathyroidism are usually round/polygonal circumscribed lesions rather than the distinctive transverse band-like lesions seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Bone pain with decreased calcium and increased phosphate, ALP, and PTH levels can be seen in patients with secondary hyperparathyroidism due to ESRD (renal osteodystrophy), as well as in patients with pseudohypoparathyroidism (PHP). Also, patients with PHP or renal osteodystrophy can have muscle weakness (due to myopathy) and radiological features of osteomalacia such as Looser zones, as seen here. However, renal osteodystrophy would not occur until the very late stage of CKD (i.e., when renal replacement therapy is required). PHP, on the other hand, would typically manifest during childhood with features of Albright hereditary osteodystrophy (e.g., short stature, round face, obesity, short fourth metacarpals, soft tissue calcifications, dental hypoplasia).

F) INCORRECT:

Osteolytic metastases, which appear as radiolucent lesions, can result in increased calcium, phosphorus, and ALP levels, together with decreased PTH levels. Bone metastases should be considered in any elderly patient with bone pain even if the primary tumor is not clinically evident. Hypercalcemia could also explain muscle weakness in this patient. However, the transverse band-like appearance of the radiolucent lesions in this woman suggests a different diagnosis, as osteolytic metastases usually appear as ill-defined, round lesions on x-ray.

G) INCORRECT:

Decreased calcium and PTH levels with normal serum ALP levels and increased phosphate are consistent with primary hypoparathyroidism, which can result in decreased muscle strength. However, features of bone disease are usually absent in patients with primary hypoparathyroidism. Moreover, in adults, primary hypoparathyroidism is typically caused by iatrogenic damage to the parathyroid glands during neck surgery (e.g., thyroidectomy) or neck irradiation.

Rarely (< 1% of cases), primary hypoparathyroidism occurs as a result of autoimmune disease or infiltrative diseases of the parathyroid glands (e.g., sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis, Wilson disease, metastases).
questions.hint: This patient's history of Crohn disease combined with her physical exam findings of pale conjunctiva and decreased vibratory sensation suggests malabsorption as the underlying cause for her bone pain. Bone pain combined with thin cortices and Looser zones (transverse radiolucent bands) on x-ray indicates osteomalacia.

questions.text:
The parents of an 18-month-old girl report that she appears to have bowing of the legs and that she seems to walk less than their other children did at the same age. She was breastfed exclusively until 6 months of age, when she started eating solid foods. She currently eats a variety of table foods and mostly drinks water and juice. She has never received vitamin supplementation.
Her weight is below the 5th percentile, and she has bilateral wrist enlargement and lower limb bowing. Radiographs are significant for generalized osteopenia, fraying and cupping of the metaphyses (especially at the wrists), and bowing of the long bones in the legs.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Intravenous vitamin D and oral calcium supplementation
Physical therapy to improve muscle and bone strength
Oral vitamin D and calcium supplementation
A diet rich in calcium and vitamin D

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treatment for vitamin D-deficiency rickets includes oral vitamin D supplementation and calcium supplementation. Intravenous vitamin D is generally not required.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy would not be effective without treatment of the underlying nutritional disorder.

C) CORRECT:

Low body weight, wrist enlargement, and leg bowing, coupled with radiographs that show osteopenia and metaphyseal fraying and cupping, are consistent with vitamin D-deficiency rickets.

This condition is caused by low nutritional intake of vitamin D and is associated with hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and bone demineralization. It is more likely to occur in infants who are exclusively breastfed and do not receive vitamin D supplementation or in infants and toddlers with darker skin pigmentation who live in northern latitudes and whose diet does not include adequate milk intake.

Physical examination findings with vitamin D-deficiency rickets include short stature, poor weight gain, wrist and ankle flaring (enlargement), craniotabes, frontal bossing, and the “rachitic rosary,” which describes palpable enlargement along the anterior costochondral ridge. Radiographic findings can include widening of the metaphyses of long bones, cup-shaped metaphyses, osteopenia, rib flaring, and fractures. Diagnosis is based on low levels of 25-hydroxyvitamin D, calcium, and phosphorus.

Treatment for vitamin D-deficiency rickets includes oral vitamin D supplementation and calcium supplementation. Recommendations for oral vitamin D treatment range from 25 μg (1000 IU) to 125 μg (5000 IU) per day for 4 to 6 weeks. For children in whom adherence is a problem, weekly dosing (50,000 IU for 8 weeks) or higher dosing in a single dose can be effective. Intravenous vitamin D is generally not required.

Key learning point: Appropriate oral therapy for vitamin D-deficiency rickets consists of both vitamin D and calcium supplementation.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D supplementation alone is not sufficient to correct the hypocalcemia associated with rickets.

E) INCORRECT:

A diet rich in calcium and vitamin D is recommended, but it is not sufficient for treating rickets.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 13-year-old boy presents with a 3-month history of fatigue and leg pain. He has had no fever or weight loss. His medical history includes surgery for malrotation and volvulus as an infant.
On examination, he has genu varum.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Calcium (mg/dL)
6.9
8.8–10.8


Phosphorus (mg/dL)
2.1
3.3–5.4


1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (pg/mL)
35
16–65


25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
<10
30–60


Parathyroid hormone (pg/mL)
105
10–60


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
820
100–390


Radiographs show metaphyseal fraying in the long bones of the extremities and diffuse osteopenia.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with 1-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency have a diminished ability to convert 25-hydroxyvitamin D into 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. They have low 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels and normal or high 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels.

B) INCORRECT:

X-linked hypophosphatemia and Fanconi syndrome both cause defective renal phosphate reabsorption and rickets. Laboratory findings include a low phosphorus level, normal or elevated calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and normal vitamin D levels.

C) INCORRECT:

X-linked hypophosphatemia and Fanconi syndrome both cause defective renal phosphate reabsorption and rickets. Laboratory findings include a low phosphorus level, normal or elevated calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and normal vitamin D levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D resistance have high levels of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D and low levels of calcium and phosphorus. They may also have alopecia.

E) CORRECT:

Laboratory diagnosis of vitamin D deficiency depends on a low level of 25-hydroxyvitamin D, which is the major circulating form of vitamin D and the best indicator of vitamin D stores. Levels of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, the active form of the vitamin, are influenced by parathyroid hormone and fluctuations in calcium and may be normal or low in vitamin D-deficiency states. Other findings in vitamin D deficiency include low calcium and phosphorus levels and elevated parathyroid hormone and alkaline phosphatase levels.

This patient's laboratory results suggest vitamin D deficiency. Risk factors for vitamin D deficiency in older children include dark skin, lack of sun exposure, vegan and vegetarian diets, and disorders of malabsorption, which can be seen after intestinal surgeries such as bowel resection or with celiac disease. Clinical manifestations of vitamin D-deficiency rickets in children include developmental delay, delayed tooth eruption, and bony deformities, including widened wrists, bowed legs, and enlarged costochondral junction on the anterior lateral aspects of the chest wall.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of rickets in a child with low 25-hydroxyvitamin D, calcium, and phosphorus levels and elevated parathyroid hormone and alkaline phosphatase levels is vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old male infant is brought in for follow-up. He was born full term to a 30-year-old mother after an uncomplicated pregnancy, including a normal 20-week ultrasound. At birth, he was noted to have relative macrocephaly, frontal bossing, shortening of the limbs, and a trident hand (a widening of the space between the third and fourth digits). Both parents are healthy, with normal stature and no significant medical history. Genetic testing to confirm the most likely diagnosis is pending. The infant has been feeding well and has returned to his birth weight.
What is the likelihood that a second child in this family will be born with the same genetic disorder as the first?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If one parent in the family had achondroplasia, the risk to a future child would be 50%. The penetrance of achondroplasia is 100%, meaning that all individuals with the pathogenic variant will have clinical manifestations of the disorder.

B) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has achondroplasia, the most common form of nonlethal skeletal dysplasia. Achondroplasia is characterized by disproportionate short stature with an average-size trunk, proximal shortening of the long bones, and shortening of the fingers and toes. Distinctive craniofacial features, including macrocephaly and frontal bossing, are often evident at birth, and most children have delayed motor development because of joint laxity and macrocephaly.

Achondroplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, such that only one copy of the relevant pathogenic variant (in the gene that codes for fibroblast growth factor receptor type 3 [ FGFR3 ]) is necessary to cause the disorder. Most cases of achondroplasia (about 80%) occur in normal-height families and are the result of a de novo pathogenic variant; the rest occur in families with at least one affected parent. Screening ultrasounds performed around 20 weeks are often normal, because the underlying defect is in endochondral ossification, and long-bone measurements do not appear abnormal until the third trimester.

The overall risk of having a child with achondroplasia is very low: approximately 1 in 25,000. The individual risk within a family depends on whether the parents have the disorder themselves. In this case, the patient has two normal-height parents, so the disorder is most likely the result of a de novo pathogenic variant. The likelihood that a second child in this family will also have the FGFR3 pathogenic variant is extremely low (1%–3%) but is not zero, as there have been rare case reports of normal-height parents having more than one child with achondroplasia. This is due to gonadal mosaicism (multiple egg cells or multiple sperm cells harboring the FGFR3 pathogenic variant).

Key learning point: The inheritance pattern for achondroplasia is autosomal dominant.

C) INCORRECT:

In autosomal recessive disorders (which require one copy of the pathogenic variant from each parent), the risk for inheriting the disease is 25%. Achondroplasia is autosomal dominant, not recessive.

D) INCORRECT:

The overall risk of having a child with achondroplasia is very low: approximately 1 in 25,000. The individual risk within a family depends on whether the parents have the disorder themselves. In this case, the patient has two normal-height parents, so the disorder is most likely the result of a de novo pathogenic variant. The likelihood that a second child in this family will also have the FGFR3 pathogenic variant is extremely low (1%–3%) but is not zero, as there have been rare case reports of normal-height parents having more than one child with achondroplasia. This is due to gonadal mosaicism (multiple egg cells or multiple sperm cells harboring the FGFR3 pathogenic variant).

E) INCORRECT:

There is no scenario where a child’s risk of having achondroplasia would be 100%, as homozygous FGFR3 pathogenic variants are lethal. Therefore, if both parents have achondroplasia, the risk of an affected live birth is 67% (25% homozygous lethal, 50% heterozygous affected, 25% wild-type healthy).

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the office for a well-child examination. His mother has noticed that he frequently falls while running. He has a seizure disorder treated with phenytoin. Examination shows decreased muscle strength in the lower extremities. There is a deep groove below the costal margins bilaterally. An x-ray of the lower extremities is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While genu varum is a normal finding in newborns, infants, and toddlers (physiological varus), the lower limbs gradually straighten until 2 years of age. The presence of varus beyond 2 years of age, along with the other clinical features with which this 6-year-old child presents, is suggestive of a pathological varus deformity.

B) INCORRECT:

Although an epiphyseal plate fracture (i.e., Salter-Harris fracture) could cause angular deformities of the affected limb (e.g., genu varum), a bilateral symmetrical occurrence is highly unlikely and would not explain this patient's other clinical features. More importantly, he has no signs of healing fractures on the x-ray, nor a history of pain, swelling, and inability to bear weight on the affected side.

C) CORRECT:

This boy presents with rickets, a condition characterized by defective bone and epiphyseal plate mineralization due to vitamin D deficiency. In this patient, this condition is most likely due to an altered vitamin D metabolism as an adverse effect of the anticonvulsant treatment he is receiving. Phenytoin, a cytochrome P450 inducer increases the catabolism of vitamin D into inactive metabolites. Decreased vitamin D levels reduce intestinal calcium absorption, resulting in hypocalcemia, secondary hyperparathyroidism, and secondary hypophosphatemia, which impair bone calcification and mineralization. Typical clinical features of rickets include myopathy, Harrison groove, genu varum, bowing of the long bones of the lower limbs, and widening of the epiphyseal plates.

The most common cause of rickets is inadequate intake of vitamin D and/or calcium.

D) INCORRECT:

Skeletal dysplasias like osteogenesis imperfecta and achondroplasia can cause growth retardation and pathological genu varum. However, other characteristic features of these conditions (e.g., blue sclerae and hearing loss for osteogenesis imperfecta; macrocephaly and short, plump extremities for achondroplasia) are not present in this child. Furthermore, skeletal dysplasias do not cause myopathy or subcostal groove.

E) INCORRECT:

Certain tumors of the bone (e.g., ossifying fibroma, Ewing sarcoma, osteosarcoma, Langerhans cell histiocytosis) can cause deformities (e.g., bowing) of the affected limb in pediatric patients. However, most bone tumors are asymptomatic or present with localized pain, swelling or pathological fractures. Bilaterally symmetrical bowing of the legs, myopathy, and a subcostal groove are inconsistent with this diagnosis.
questions.hint: The x-ray shows bilateral genu varum, widening of the epiphyseal plates, and metaphyseal fraying and cupping.

questions.text: An exclusively breast-fed, 5-day-old boy is brought to the office by his mother for a routine examination. He was born at term and delivery was uncomplicated. He received all standard treatment and testing prior to being discharged from the hospital 3 days ago. Examination shows no abnormalities. Without receiving additional supplementation at this time, this newborn is at greatest risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of niacin, also known as pellagra, could result in scaly dermatitis, diarrhea, and eventually neurological symptoms (e.g., dementia). However, niacin does not typically need to be supplemented in infants' diets as adequate amounts are found in both breast milk and in most formulas. In the absence of comorbidities (e.g., malnutrition, Hartnup disease), pellagra is unlikely to develop in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

A deficiency in vitamin K greatly increases the risk of developing an intracranial bleed in early infancy. All newborn infants receive an injection of intramuscular vitamin K at birth to prevent this deficiency. This patient has already received this intervention as part of standard hospital care, and no more supplementation is necessary. Although levels of vitamin K in breast milk are low, most infants do not require additional supplementation after the initial injection, unless comorbidities are present (e.g., chronic diarrhea or long-term antibiotic treatment).

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to peripheral neuropathy. However, most breastfed infants receive adequate vitamin B12 from their mother's breast milk. Vitamin B12 supplementation during infancy is typically only required when the patient's mother follows a strict vegan diet because vitamin B12 mostly comes from animal products (e.g., meat, fish, and dairy).

D) CORRECT:

The vitamin D content of breast milk is not considered to be high enough to prevent complications from developing in infants. Therefore, vitamin D supplementation is recommended in all exclusively breastfed infants until the recommended daily vitamin D intake through diet is met. Dietary sources of vitamin D include ≥ 34 oz/day of infant formula, solid foods, and, once the infant is 12 months old, vitamin D-fortified whole milk. This supplementation protects against hypocalcemia and rickets, a disease of bone deformities in children due to a deficiency of vitamin D. Rickets is characterized by impaired calcification of the bones, delayed closure of the fontanelles, frontal bossing, prominence of costochondral junctions (“rachitic rosary”), and genu valgum or genu varum. Children with rickets present with varying degrees of pain, poor growth, motor delays, and an increased risk of infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Scurvy, caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, leads to impaired collagen synthesis that would manifest with petechiae, hyperkeratosis, and coiled hairs. Vitamin C does not typically need to be supplemented in infants' diets as adequate amounts are found in both breast milk and in most formulas. Therefore, in the absence of severe malnutrition or malabsorption, this patient is unlikely to need additional vitamin C supplementation.
questions.hint: A deficiency of this micronutrient can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to difficulty walking and leg deformities. He has been exclusively breastfed with minimal outdoor activity. Growth parameters are at the 10th percentile. Examination shows bowing of the legs, widened wrists, and mild costochondral beading (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Calcium
1.9 mmol/L
2.15 - 2.62 mmol/L


Phosphate, inorganic
0.6 mmol/L
0.82 - 1.51 mmol/L


Alkaline phosphatase
450 IU/L
100 - 320 IU/L


Renal function
Normal
Normal



Radiographs of the wrists: Cupping and fraying of the metaphyses
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vitamin D is essential for the absorption of calcium and phosphorus, crucial for bone mineralization. The child's symptoms, including bowed legs, widened wrists, and costochondral beading, along with hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase, indicate nutritional vitamin D deficiency rickets. Radiographic findings of metaphyseal cupping and fraying further support this diagnosis. Daily vitamin D supplementation replenishes deficient stores, normalizes calcium and phosphate absorption, and promotes bone mineralization, addressing the underlying cause of rickets.

Key learning point: Rickets in children, characterized by bone pain and deformities such as bowed legs, is commonly due to vitamin D deficiency, especially in cases of limited sun exposure and lack of dietary supplementation.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypophosphatemia in this context results from vitamin D deficiency, leading to reduced intestinal absorption of calcium and phosphate. Addressing the vitamin D deficiency will correct the mineral imbalance. Phosphate supplementation is indicated in conditions like X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets, characterized by renal phosphate wasting, not in nutritional rickets.

C) INCORRECT:

Orthopedic surgery is not the initial step for metabolic bone disorders like rickets. The child's deformities result from vitamin D deficiency, leading to poor bone mineralization. Surgical intervention on under-mineralized bone can result in inadequate healing. Addressing the metabolic cause first allows for potential remodeling and stabilization of bone quality.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcitriol, the active form of vitamin D, is used when renal conversion is impaired, such as in chronic kidney disease or hereditary rickets. This child has normal renal function, indicating intact conversion capacity. Nutritional vitamin D deficiency should be treated with cholecalciferol or ergocalciferol, not calcitriol, to restore normal metabolic pathways.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy with a 2-year history of celiac disease presents to the clinic with progressive leg bowing and wrist pain. He has occasional diarrhea and poor weight gain. He is below the 5th percentile for height and has widened wrists (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Calcium
2.0 mmol/L
2.15 - 2.62 mmol/L


Phosphate, inorganic
0.7 mmol/L
0.82 - 1.51 mmol/L


Alkaline phosphatase
400 IU/L
100 - 320 IU/L



Wrist radiographs: Metaphyseal cupping, fraying, and widening
Which nutrient deficiency is most likely contributing to these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency primarily presents with bleeding diathesis due to impaired gamma-carboxylation of coagulation factors. It does not cause skeletal deformities or the radiographic and laboratory findings seen in this patient, such as metaphyseal cupping, hypocalcemia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin E deficiency is associated with neurological symptoms such as ataxia and peripheral neuropathy, not skeletal abnormalities. The clinical and radiographic findings in this patient, including leg bowing and metaphyseal changes, indicate a defect in bone mineralization, which is not related to vitamin E deficiency.

C) CORRECT:

Celiac disease impairs absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, including vitamin D, which is essential for calcium and phosphate homeostasis. Vitamin D deficiency leads to decreased intestinal absorption of these minerals, resulting in hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia. This stimulates osteoblast activity, increasing alkaline phosphatase levels. In children, these disturbances manifest as rickets, characterized by defective mineralization of the growth plate, leading to clinical signs such as widened wrists and leg bowing. Radiographic findings of metaphyseal cupping, fraying, and widening further indicate vitamin D deficiency-related rickets.

Key learning point: In children with celiac disease presenting with signs of rickets, an X-ray of the wrist joint showing cupping, fraying, and widening of the metaphysis is a key diagnostic tool for confirming rickets.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, which presents with impaired collagen synthesis, leading to gum bleeding, bruising, and subperiosteal hemorrhages. It does not cause bone deformities or the radiographic features of metaphyseal cupping, fraying, and widening. Additionally, vitamin C deficiency does not typically result in hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, or elevated alkaline phosphatase.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to your clinic for a well-child examination. His mother reports that he frequently falls while running. He has a history of seizure disorder and is treated with phenytoin. On examination, he has decreased muscle strength in the lower extremities and a deep groove below the costal margins bilaterally. An x-ray of the lower extremities is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Certain tumors of the bone (e.g., ossifying fibroma, Ewing sarcoma, osteosarcoma, Langerhans cell histiocytosis) can cause deformities (e.g., bowing) of the affected limb in pediatric patients. However, most bone tumors are asymptomatic or present with localized pain, swelling or pathological fractures. Bilaterally symmetrical bowing of the legs, myopathy, and a subcostal groove are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

This boy presents with rickets, a condition characterized by defective bone and epiphyseal plate mineralization due to vitamin D deficiency. In this patient, this condition is most likely due to an altered vitamin D metabolism as an adverse effect of the anticonvulsant treatment he is receiving. Phenytoin, a cytochrome P450 inducer increases the catabolism of vitamin D into inactive metabolites. Decreased vitamin D levels reduce intestinal calcium absorption, resulting in hypocalcemia, secondary hyperparathyroidism, and secondary hypophosphatemia, which impair bone calcification and mineralization. Typical clinical features of rickets include myopathy, Harrison groove, genu varum, bowing of the long bones of the lower limbs, and widening of the epiphyseal plates.

The most common cause of rickets is inadequate intake of vitamin D and/or calcium.

Key learning point: Rickets is a metabolic bone disorder caused by vitamin D deficiency or impaired vitamin D metabolism, leading to defective bone mineralization and characteristic skeletal deformities in children.

C) INCORRECT:

While genu varum is a normal finding in newborns, infants, and toddlers (physiological varus), the lower limbs gradually straighten until 2 years of age. The presence of varus beyond 2 years of age, along with the other clinical features with which this 6-year-old child presents, is suggestive of a pathological varus deformity.

D) INCORRECT:

Although an epiphyseal plate fracture (i.e., Salter-Harris fracture) could cause angular deformities of the affected limb (e.g., genu varum), a bilateral symmetrical occurrence is highly unlikely and would not explain this patient's other clinical features. More importantly, he has no signs of healing fractures on the x-ray, nor a history of pain, swelling, and inability to bear weight on the affected side.

E) INCORRECT:

Skeletal dysplasias like osteogenesis imperfecta and achondroplasia can cause growth retardation and pathological genu varum. However, other characteristic features of these conditions (e.g., blue sclerae and hearing loss for osteogenesis imperfecta; macrocephaly and short, plump extremities for achondroplasia) are not present in this child. Furthermore, skeletal dysplasias do not cause myopathy or subcostal groove.
questions.hint: The x-ray shows bilateral genu varum, widening of the epiphyseal plates, and metaphyseal fraying and cupping.

questions.text: You are seeing a 5-day-old boy who is exclusively breast-fed and brought to your clinic by his mother for a routine examination. He was born at term following an uncomplicated delivery and received all standard treatment and testing before being discharged from the hospital 3 days ago. Examination is normal. Without additional supplementation at this time, this newborn is at greatest risk of developing which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of niacin, also known as pellagra, could result in scaly dermatitis, diarrhea, and eventually neurological symptoms (e.g., dementia). However, niacin does not typically need to be supplemented in infants' diets as adequate amounts are found in both breast milk and in most formulas. In the absence of comorbidities (e.g., malnutrition, Hartnup disease), pellagra is unlikely to develop in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

A deficiency in vitamin K greatly increases the risk of developing an intracranial bleed in early infancy. All newborn infants receive an injection of intramuscular vitamin K at birth to prevent this deficiency. This patient has already received this intervention as part of standard hospital care, and no more supplementation is necessary. Although levels of vitamin K in breast milk are low, most infants do not require additional supplementation after the initial injection, unless comorbidities are present (e.g., chronic diarrhea or long-term antibiotic treatment).

C) CORRECT:

The vitamin D content of breast milk is not considered to be high enough to prevent complications from developing in infants. Therefore, vitamin D supplementation is recommended in all exclusively breastfed infants until the recommended daily vitamin D intake through diet is met. Dietary sources of vitamin D include ≥ 34 oz/day of infant formula, solid foods, and, once the infant is 12 months old, vitamin D-fortified whole milk. This supplementation protects against hypocalcemia and rickets, a disease of bone deformities in children due to a deficiency of vitamin D. Rickets is characterized by impaired calcification of the bones, delayed closure of the fontanelles, frontal bossing, prominence of costochondral junctions (“rachitic rosary”), and genu valgum or genu varum. Children with rickets present with varying degrees of pain, poor growth, motor delays, and an increased risk of infections.

Key learning point: Exclusively breastfed infants require vitamin D supplementation to prevent rickets, as breast milk alone does not provide sufficient vitamin D.

D) INCORRECT:

Scurvy, caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, leads to impaired collagen synthesis that would manifest with petechiae, hyperkeratosis, and coiled hairs. Vitamin C does not typically need to be supplemented in infants' diets as adequate amounts are found in both breast milk and in most formulas. Therefore, in the absence of severe malnutrition or malabsorption, this patient is unlikely to need additional vitamin C supplementation.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to peripheral neuropathy. However, most breastfed infants receive adequate vitamin B12 from their mother's breast milk. Vitamin B12 supplementation during infancy is typically only required when the patient's mother follows a strict vegan diet because vitamin B12 mostly comes from animal products (e.g., meat, fish, and dairy).
questions.hint: A deficiency of this micronutrient can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a 4-month history of progressive bone pain and proximal muscle weakness. Medical history is remarkable for gastric bypass surgery 2 years ago. She has difficulty rising from a chair and climbing stairs. Physical examination shows a waddling gait, diffuse bone tenderness, and proximal muscle weakness. Laboratory studies show serum calcium 7.8 mg/dL, phosphorus 2.0 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase 220 U/L, and elevated parathyroid hormone. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bisphosponates are used in the treatment of osteoporosis. This patient more likely has osteomalacia, making an alternative treatment more appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids are indicated for polymyalgia rheumatica, which manifests with muscle weakness, elevated inflammatory markers, and normal calcium metabolism. While this patient has proximal muscle weakness, their laboratory findings of hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and elevated parathyroid hormone are not consistent with this inflammatory condition. An alternative step in management is required in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Parathyroidectomy is indicated for primary hyperparathyroidism (inappropriately elevated parathyroid hormone with hypercalcemia) but is inappropriate when PTH is elevated as a physiological response to hypocalcemia (secondary hyperparathyroidism).

D) INCORRECT:

IV calcium gluconate is reserved for severe, symptomatic hypocalcemia with signs such as tetany, seizures, or cardiac arrhythmias, not for chronic hypocalcemia without cardiac or neurological symptoms. This patient's hypocalcemia is secondary to an underlying cause, which requires an alternative step in management.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's presentation (bone pain, proximal muscle weakness, waddling gait, hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and elevated parathyroid hormone) suggests classic osteomalacia secondary to vitamin D deficiency, likely caused by malabsorption from gastric bypass surgery. High-dose vitamin D supplementation with adequate calcium intake is the appropriate initial treatment to address the underlying deficiency and restore normal bone mineralization.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father for evaluation of intermittent muscle cramps for the past year and short stature. She has had recurrent upper respiratory tract infections since infancy. She is at the 5th percentile for weight and 10th percentile for height. Physical examination shows nasal polyps and dry skin. An x-ray of the right wrist shows osteopenia with epiphyseal widening. Which of the following sets of laboratory findings is most likely in this patient's serum?



Calcium
Phosphorus
Parathyroid hormone
Calcitriol



A
↓
↓
↑
↓


B
↓
↑
↑
↓


C
↓
↑
↓
↓


D
↑
↓
↑
↑


E
Normal
↓
↑
↓
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This laboratory constellation is consistent with vitamin D deficiency. In this patient with findings suggestive of CF, vitamin D deficiency is most likely due to malabsorption. Decreased vitamin D levels reduce intestinal calcium absorption, resulting in hypocalcemia, which, in turn, stimulates PTH secretion. PTH decreases phosphate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules, leading to hypophosphatemia. This patient's muscle cramps are likely due to hypocalcemia. Also, the patient's x-ray findings of osteopenia with an epiphyseal widening of the wrist are suggestive of rickets, which is most commonly caused by chronic vitamin D deficiency.

Further symptoms of hypocalcemia include paresthesias, Trousseau sign and Chvostek sign, ECG changes (QT prolongation), and, in severe cases, seizures.

B) INCORRECT:

This laboratory constellation is consistent with chronic kidney disease (CKD). Patients with CKD commonly have vitamin D deficiency due to impaired 1-alpha hydroxylase activity. Low vitamin D levels lead to decreased intestinal calcium absorption. Hypocalcemia stimulates PTH secretion (secondary hyperparathyroidism), which normally increases renal reabsorption of calcium and excretion of phosphate. However, since renal phosphate excretion is impaired in CKD, hyperphosphatemia is classically seen. In a patient with CF, a different set of laboratory findings would be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

This laboratory constellation is consistent with primary hypoparathyroidism. PTH is a key modulator of calcium and phosphate homeostasis and insufficient secretion from the parathyroid glands (e.g., due to thyroidectomy or parathyroidectomy, autoimmune disease, or genetic disease (e.g., DiGeorge syndrome)) results in hypocalcemia. This is due to decreased mobilization of calcium from bones, decreased tubular calcium reabsorption, and decreased synthesis of calcitriol leading to impaired intestinal absorption of calcium. Since PTH normally inhibits tubular phosphate reabsorption, low levels result in hyperphosphatemia. In a patient with CF, a different set of laboratory findings would be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

This laboratory constellation can be seen in primary hyperparathyroidism (pHPT). In pHPT, which is most commonly caused by parathyroid gland adenomas, elevated PTH levels result in hypercalcemia due to increased mobilization of calcium from bones, increased tubular calcium reabsorption, and increased intestinal absorption of calcium via stimulation of calcitriol synthesis. In addition, PTH inhibits tubular phosphate reabsorption, resulting in hypophosphatemia. In a patient with CF, a different set of laboratory findings would be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

This laboratory constellation is consistent with hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets (HHR). Individuals with HHR have high circulating levels of fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF 23), a protein synthesized by osteoblasts. High FGF 23 results in decreased renal phosphate reabsorption leading to hypophosphatemia. In addition, increased PTH secretion, normal calcium levels, and normal or mildly reduced calcitriol levels are seen. Clinical manifestations of HHR include features of rickets (e.g., short stature, failure to thrive), which are also seen in this patient. However, HHR is not associated with recurrent upper respiratory tract infections or nasal polyps. In a patient with CF, a different set of laboratory findings would be expected.
questions.hint: This patient with recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, nasal polyps, and features of malabsorption (e.g., failure to thrive, dry skin) most likely has cystic fibrosis (CF). Her muscle cramps are related to an electrolyte abnormality.

questions.text: A 14-month-old boy has delayed walking, wrist widening, and is exclusively breastfed without supplementation for over a year. What is the most appropriate therapy to address his underlying deficiency?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While calcium is essential for bone health, the boy's symptoms and history suggest vitamin D deficiency, not isolated calcium deficiency. Vitamin D is crucial for calcium absorption, and without it, increased dietary calcium alone will not correct the underlying metabolic dysfunction.

B) CORRECT:

The 14-month-old boy's symptoms, including delayed walking and wrist widening, suggest nutritional rickets due to vitamin D deficiency from exclusive breastfeeding without supplementation. Cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) is preferred for treatment as it is efficiently converted in the liver to 25-hydroxyvitamin D, the main circulating form, and then to its active form in the kidneys. This conversion enhances intestinal absorption of calcium and phosphorus, crucial for bone mineralization and skeletal development. Supplementing with cholecalciferol directly addresses the deficiency, improving calcium homeostasis and resolving rickets-related skeletal issues.

Key learning point: Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) is the preferred form of vitamin D for the treatment of nutritional rickets due to its effectiveness in raising and maintaining blood vitamin D levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Ergocalciferol (vitamin D2) is less effective than cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) in raising serum vitamin D levels in pediatric patients. Cholecalciferol is more potent and has a longer half-life, making it the preferred choice for treating vitamin D deficiency in children.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcitriol, the active form of vitamin D, is used when there is impaired renal conversion of 25-hydroxyvitamin D, such as in chronic kidney disease. This patient has nutritional vitamin D deficiency, which does not impair conversion, making cholecalciferol more appropriate.
